Stuff about partially ordered abelian groups

Feb 29, 2020

I’m in the process of writing up the result of this post now, and along the way, proved some interesting results which I’d like to state in this post. Recall some notation: suppose is a partially ordered abelian group; then, one can form a spectral scheme and a spectral group scheme acting on . (The reader should keep in mind the example , in which case and .) Let denote the category of presentable stable -categories, and let denote the -category of presentable stable -categories equipped with an action of the partially ordered abelian group . I’ll state the result of the previous post as well as its categorification in the same theorem statement.

Theorem: There is an equivalence of symmetric monoidal -categories. If is linearly reductive, then there is an equivalence .

One can replace with for any -ring , and then has to be taken to mean the stack over . If , then admits a -structure, known as the Beilinson -structure, whose heart is the abelian category of chain complexes over . It turns out that for general , the category still admits a -structure, but I don’t know a good description of the heart.

Now, there was a nice paper that came out on the arXiv recently, which described the Balmer spectrum of for certain . Motivated by this result and the theorem that , I was curious as to whether one could describe the Balmer spectrum of spectral algebraic stacks. The answer turns out to be yes in a large number of cases! To state the result, we need to introduce and recall some definitions. We shall also -localize everywhere for a fixed prime, just to state our results in a simpler way. This is really just for cosmetic purposes.

This paper introduces the notion of “cohomological properness”. We need a slight modification of this definition. Let be a morphism of quasi-geometric spectral algebraic stacks. Say that is cohomologically proper if the pushforward takes perfect objects of to perfect objects of . If , we simply say that is cohomologically proper. It’s fairly straightforward to show that if is a partially ordered abelian group, then pushforward along the structure morphism preserves compact object, but not necessarily perfect objects — the issue is that could be absolutely massive (it is true, however, that is cohomologically proper if is linearly reductive). For another example, Theorem 6.1.3.2 of SAG shows that any morphism of spectral Deligne-Mumford stacks which is proper, locally of finite presentation, and finite Tor-amplitude is cohomologically proper in this sense.

We finally need another definition, motived by this paper. A quasi-geometric spectral algebraic stack with underlying stack is said to be weakly regular if pushforward along the morphism sends perfect objects to perfect objects. What we prove is the following:

Theorem: Let be a morphism of weakly regular quasi-geometric spectral algebraic stacks. Suppose that:

  • is of finite cohomological dimension;
  • is flat and cohomologically proper;
  • is in the thick subcategory of generated by .

Then the map induces a homeomorphism

The main result of this paper allows one to further describe the underlying space of as when has quasi-finite and separated diagonal. In this case, we find that there is a homeomorphism between the Balmer spectrum and .

Although it might seem like there are a lot of hypotheses in the theorem, these assumptions are satisfied by every morphism of weakly regular quasicompact quasiseparated spectral algebraic spaces, whose underlying algebraic spaces are of finite cohomological dimension, which is proper, flat, and locally of finite presentation. So this theorem describes the Balmer spectrum of lots of spectral algebraic stacks.

The assumptions of the theorem are (almost) satisfied when is a partially ordered abelian group such that is finitely generated and is linearly reductive. One might therefore wish to describe the underlying space purely in terms of , and perhaps obtain a description of the Balmer spectrum of (under the equivalence of the first theorem) analogously to this paper. We can do that, too: in toric geometry, there is a classical result called the orbit-cone correspondence. A generalization of this was proven by Ogus(?) for applications in log geometry, and one can extend his arguments to describe the underlying space in terms of for any partially ordered abelian group.

Finally, in algebraic geometry, and are moduli spaces of line bundles and line bundles equipped with a section (“generalized effective Cartier divisors”). One can provide a similar moduli-theoretic interpretation for , but the description is a little more complicated. This is in part because the flat multiplicative group in spectral algebraic geometry is not the same as the functor sending a ring to its group of units. But it’s easy to get past this issue.

Hopefully this stuff will appear online soon!
